comment.author: 29877325@N07
comment._content: WOW!!!  Good photo. The speed may have change but the hostility to beat the opponent remains...that's history. Weaponry and the players can change...as well as the circumstances and countries involved. An old foe can become today's NATO ally, ha,ha,ha. Like Sinatra said, "that's life..."

comment.author: 31451801@N07
comment._content: Wow, it's scary to think of flying in one of those things! And it's amazing how much progress aviation made in just a few years if you compare these to the planes that were flying at the end of the war!

comment.author: 44701338@N08
comment._content: .....riding high in april...shot down in may, that's life....that's what all the people say..

comment.author: 66679836@N02
comment._content: Is t his a photo that was staged after the war?   I would think so, the Taubes were obsolete pretty quickly and only used for training purposes mostly after the war started.   As far as I know anyway.   They had no armament, and probably could only be used for observation, but didn't have an observer seat...  but being rather forgiving to fly, and the quantity of them, they were widely used as training aircraft.   So I think this confrontation would be unlikely, and even more unlikely, that it get caught on film in a fly by.
